full_text:
--- Page 1 ---

 
 
ST ATEMENT
 
OF
 
INTENT
 
NKWOR
 
JANE
 
CHINELO
 
 
I
 
aim
 
to
 
develop
 
reinforcement
 
learning
 
methods
 
that
 
learn
 
efficiently
 
from
 
sparse,
 
noisy ,
 
or
 
delayed
 
feedback
 
and
 
generalise
 
reliably
 
across
 
real-world
 
environments.
 
This
 
research
 
direction
 
emer ged
 
from
 
an
 
unexpected
 
path:
 
during
 
a
 
2018
 
university
 
strike,
 
I
 
enrolled
 
in
 
a
 
programming
 
school
 
and
 
discovered
 
a
 
deep
 
fascination
 
with
 
how
 
systems
 
represent
 
information,
 
make
 
decisions,
 
and
 
adapt
 
to
 
uncertain
 
environments
 
–
 
a
 
curiosity
 
that
 
has
 
since
 
crystallised
 
into
 
this
 
focused
 
research
 
ambition.
 
This
 
ambition
 
crystallised
 
during
 
my
 
master ’s
 
dissertation,
 
Development
 
of
 
an
 
Autonomous
 
Agent
 
for
 
a
 
Number
 
Strategy
 
Game
 
Using
 
Deep
 
Q-Networks
.
 
Motivated
 
by
 
an
 
interest
 
in
 
how
 
systems—biological
 
or
 
artificial—learn
 
under
 
uncertainty ,
 
I
 
developed
 
a
 
DQN-based
 
agent
 
augmented
 
with
 
Prioritised
 
Experience
 
Replay .
 
I
 
trained
 
and
 
evaluated
 
the
 
agent
 
across
 
thousands
 
of
 
episodes,
 
comparing
 
its
 
performance
 
to
 
deterministic
 
baselines
 
such
 
as
 
Minimax
 
and
 
Reservoir
 
Sampling.
 
The
 
DQN
 
achieved
 
an
 
over
 
85%
 
success
 
rate
 
by
 
generalising
 
from
 
experience
 
rather
 
than
 
relying
 
on
 
exhaustive
 
computation
 
–
 
findings
 
I
 
have
 
documented
 
in
 
a
 
manuscript
 
currently
 
under
 
review
 
and
 
a
 
conference
 
paper
 
accepted
 
for
 
presentation
 
in
 
2025.
 
The
 
work
 
was
 
technically
 
demanding:
 
I
 
confronted
 
vanishing
 
rewards,
 
unstable
 
training
 
dynamics,
 
and
 
sensitivity
 
to
 
hyperparameters.
 
Overcoming
 
these
 
challenges
 
required
 
designing
 
custom
 
reward-shaping
 
strategies,
 
adjusting
 
network
 
architectures,
 
and
 
experimenting
 
with
 
exploration
 
schedules
 
to
 
optimise
 
performance.
 
More
 
importantly ,
 
the
 
project
 
revealed
 
deeper
 
limitations
 
with
 
standard
 
DQN
 
methods—overestimation
 
bias,
 
poor
 
sample
 
efficiency ,
 
and
 
fragility
 
in
 
high-dimensional
 
settings.
 
These
 
gaps
 
highlight
 
a
 
central
 
challenge:
 
deploying
 
RL
 
agents
 
in
 
real-world
 
environments
 
requires
 
learning
 
from
 
imperfect
 

--- Page 2 ---

signals
 
(sparse
 
rewards,
 
delays),
 
adapting
 
across
 
diverse
 
contexts
 
(transfer
 
learning),
 
and
 
doing
 
so
 
safely
 
(robustness,
 
trustworthiness).
 
My
 
doctoral
 
research
 
will
 
address
 
these
 
interconnected
 
challenges.
 
Alongside
 
reinforcement
 
learning,
 
I
 
am
 
actively
 
pursuing
 
interdisciplinary
 
experiences
 
that
 
continue
 
to
 
shape
 
my
 
understanding
 
of
 
intelligent
 
systems.
 
In
 
September
 
2025,
 
I
 
participated
 
in
 
the
 
AltSchool
 
Africa
 
Hackathon
 
with
 
two
 
other
 
women,
 
where
 
we
 
developed
 
an
 
LLM-
 
and
 
RAG-powered
 
backend
 
system
 
for
 
Nigerian
 
business
 
regulatory
 
assistance
 
and
 
placed
 
third
 
overall.
 
This
 
experience
 
strengthened
 
my
 
appreciation
 
for
 
collaborative
 
problem-solving,
 
rapid
 
prototyping,
 
and
 
the
 
importance
 
of
 
grounding
 
AI
 
systems
 
in
 
real
 
regulatory
 
and
 
user
 
contexts.
 
Building
 
on
 
this
 
perspective,
 
I
 
began
 
working
 
in
 
November
 
2025
 
as
 
a
 
Technical
 
Assistant
 
on
 
a
 
grant-funded
 
Thought
 
Management
 
Therapy
 
project,
 
a
 
role
 
I
 
continue
 
to
 
hold.
 
In
 
this
 
position,
 
I
 
support
 
the
 
development
 
of
 
digital
 
psychological
 
assessment
 
tools,
 
conduct
 
statistical
 
analyses
 
on
 
participant
 
data,
 
and
 
collaborate
 
with
 
psychologists
 
and
 
computer
 
scientists
 
to
 
validate
 
assessment
 
instruments.
 
This
 
ongoing
 
work
 
has
 
deepened
 
my
 
conviction
 
that
 
trustworthy
 
and
 
effective
 
AI
 
systems
 
must
 
be
 
informed
 
by
 
human
 
cognition,
 
behavioral
 
patterns,
 
and
 
mental
 
workload,
 
particularly
 
when
 
deployed
 
in
 
sensitive,
 
real-world
 
settings.
 
 
Across
 
my
 
experiences
 
in
 
reinforcement
 
learning,
 
language
 
modelling,
 
and
 
psychological
 
assessment,
 
I
 
have
 
come
 
to
 
appreciate
 
that
 
building
 
trustworthy
 
autonomous
 
systems
 
requires
 
more
 
than
 
algorithmic
 
sophistication.
 
RL
 
provides
 
me
 
with
 
the
 
tools
 
to
 
model
 
adaptive
 
decision-making.
 
LLM
 
systems
 
expose
 
me
 
to
 
representation
 
learning
 
and
 
knowledge
 
grounding.
 
Psychological
 
research
 
teaches
 
me
 
how
 
humans
 
perceive,
 
trust,
 
and
 
interact
 
with
 
intelligent
 
systems.
 
Together ,
 
these
 
experiences
 
shape
 
my
 
goal
 
of
 
developing
 
autonomous
 

--- Page 3 ---

agents
 
that
 
are
 
not
 
only
 
technically
 
robust
 
but
 
aligned
 
with
 
human
 
cognitive
 
and
 
behavioural
 
realities.
 
The
 
University
 
of
 
Notre
 
Dame
 
is
 
the
 
ideal
 
environment
 
for
 
advancing
 
this
 
vision.
 
I
 
am
 
particularly
 
drawn
 
to
 
Professor
 
Toby
 
Jia-Jun
 
Li’s
 
work
 
in
 
end-user
 
software
 
engineering,
 
natural
 
language
 
interfaces,
 
and
 
human-AI
 
collaboration.
 
His
 
research
 
aligns
 
directly
 
with
 
my
 
long-term
 
goal
 
of
 
developing
 
autonomous
 
agents
 
and
 
LLM-driven
 
tools
 
that
 
are
 
intuitive,
 
interactive,
 
and
 
grounded
 
in
 
human
 
contexts.
 
Professor
 
Meng
 
Jiang’ s
 
research
 
in
 
NLP,
 
heterogeneous
 
graph
 
learning,
 
and
 
knowledge-augmented
 
LLMs
 
connects
 
naturally
 
to
 
my
 
interest
 
in
 
enabling
 
autonomous
 
agents
 
to
 
understand
 
structured
 
relationships
 
and
 
perform
 
higher -level
 
reasoning.
 
Additionally ,
 
Professor
 
Yanfang
 
(Fanny)
 
Ye’s
 
work
 
on
 
trustworthy
 
AI
 
and
 
robust
 
LLM
 
systems
 
resonates
 
strongly
 
with
 
my
 
aim
 
to
 
develop
 
reliable,
 
safe
 
autonomous
 
agents
 
for
 
high-stakes
 
applications.
 
Together ,
 
these
 
faculty
 
members
 
represent
 
a
 
uniquely
 
complementary
 
set
 
of
 
strengths
 
that
 
fits
 
my
 
interdisciplinary
 
background
 
in
 
RL,
 
LLM
 
applications,
 
and
 
human-centred
 
system
 
design.
 
A
 
PhD
 
is
 
the
 
essential
 
next
 
step
 
for
 
me
 
to
 
pursue
 
these
 
research
 
questions
 
with
 
the
 
depth
 
and
 
rigour
 
they
 
require.
 
My
 
goal
 
is
 
to
 
become
 
a
 
research
 
scientist
 
developing
 
adaptive,
 
stable,
 
trustworthy
 
autonomous
 
systems
 
that
 
can
 
operate
 
safely
 
in
 
complex
 
environments.
 
Notre
 
Dame’ s
 
emphasis
 
on
 
human-centred
 
computing,
 
socially
 
impactful
 
research,
 
and
 
interdisciplinary
 
collaboration
 
provides
 
the
 
perfect
 
setting
 
for
 
me
 
to
 
grow
 
into
 
an
 
independent
 
researcher .
 
I
 
look
 
forward
 
to
 
contributing
 
my
 
technical
 
background,
 
research
 
curiosity ,
 
and
 
commitment
 
to
 
socially
 
responsible
 
AI
 
to
 
Notre
 
Dame’ s
 
doctoral
 
community .
